data.text: The Volume of Panniers: How do you decide the volume needed?

hello to all 游 Do you have any tips or feedback regarding the volume of bags needed? Context: As part of a month-long bike journey, a year later, I'd like to purchase some bags. I would go camping with the tent, sleeping bag and mattress along with kitchen utensils and of course clothes. I hesitate between the orlieb back roller plus 2x20L either 40L or 2x35L or 70L. However, I fear that 40L is too little and 70L is too bulky. Do you have any experiences with the pair of 70 liter bags?
Better to have space in a bag and not needing it than needing space in a bag and not having it.
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: but it is also true that the more space you have, the less careful you are when choosing what to take and you end up taking more things which translates into more weight

data.text: that is called discipline. And in most cases the "taking more than you need" problem is resolved during a test ride, where the additional weight will come into play. Then there will be a lot of free space again. If it can't by done discipline, then lesson-learned will.
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: correct, I learned over time, today I have the same paper checklist as 10 years ago, many items are crossed out

data.text: 2x20L is too little for me especially for a year trip, but I will avoid 2x35L because all the weight would be on the back of the bike. In my opinion, the best combination would be 2x20L in the back and 2x12.5L in the front (if you choose Ortlieb bags)

data.text: lost, 40+25 and I'm going! Then you can add a bag to your bags (for like tent and sleeping bag).

data.text: To be more precise, before I had to store my kitchen / tools for the bike, and what to eat for 4-5 days. And larriere, a bag for mainly the fringes, and the other for sleeping and a few other things
data.author: Julien Gohier

data.text: it depends on how much you want to be charged I prefer not to take oversized bags because I tend to overfill them otherwise. Otherwise I am finishing a year long journey and I have exactly what Joel is proposing. Sounds like perfect to me. It distributes the weight of the bags and not only pull your luggage but also push them. In particular, it prevents back pain.
data.author: Choux-chat Xuxa

data.text: I don't know my volume in ltrs but I have 2 panniers each about 5kg . One ois for tent and sleeping gear +. The other is mostly for clothing etc.. I also have a top bag which weighs around 4kgs. This contains cooking stove and food. My front roll bag will have my phone and waterproof clothing
data.author: David O'Donnell

data.text: I try to get as lightweight as possible. I learned to take on a 1 year long trip as much as I would take for three days. However I am freezing very quickly, though I take a couple of long sleeves, thin woolen jumpers and 2 pairs of long, thin woolen underwear (trousers). Keep in mind, you always find a place to wash your clothes. Though I have two VAUDE environment friendly aqua back panniers - with two smaller outer pockets. They have 25 l each, a silkroad bag (on the rear rack), but only because of my medicines and that I am a woman. I also will have a handlebar bag. Last year I had a 30 l big bag on the rack for my winter coat, which was too clumsy for me - maybe it would be good for the tent, maddrass etc. 1 pic = last year, 2 pic = this year
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: The bigger the bag the more you sail . A small bag forces you to grab efficiency .
data.author: Christiaan Minderhoud

data.text: Preferably you should travel light weight. When you are out in wilderness, then frugal living style has its own taste. If you wish to live lavish then such adventure has no charm. Avoid carrying too much of a stuff, however no compromise on your clothing etc , as you sweat our a lot, evening youvwish to relax after a shower and a good dinner. Bon voyage.
data.author: Pradeep Kotnala

data.text: 70 is way too big. I have two 40 and two 20 with a rackpack for my tent and sleeping gear.
